item.title: E2E Tests are the Most Important
item.description: End-to-End (E2E) tests are the most important tests for a piece of software because they are the technical implementation of the contract between the software creator and its users. If all your E2E tests pass, then the contract is fulfilled. Linus Torvalds, the creator and maintainer of Linux, one of the biggest open-source projects, famously said “WE DO NOT BREAK USERSPACE!” (an opinion which he consistently expresses). He values: Not breaking the contract between the kernel and user-space programs Don’t make changes to the contact that’s incompatible with previous contracts Now, I’d bet the software you’re writing have fewer dependents than the Linux kernel, and you can change the contract more freely, but the purpose of this article is to drill home the point that you should not break contracts.
